text: Intuitively it looks like a really small sample. ROI seems a bit unrealistically high as well for pre-race trading as well. That’s not to say it won’t be profitable, but it’s unlikely to sustain that ROI in the long term, and you’ve got 10% there due to a small sample.

text: As an alternative to the t-test, you could do a simple Monte Carlo sum in Excel over 1000 bets. Give them odds of 2 (or randomise over a range). Then give either no edge or a small edge to actual probabilities and see what charts look like after refreshing the sheet.

elements.text: As an alternative to the t-test, you could do a simple Monte Carlo sum in Excel over 1000 bets. Give them odds of 2 (or randomise over a range). Then give either no edge or a small edge to actual probabilities and see what charts look like after refreshing the sheet.

text: It’ll give you an idea of what a returns chart would look like given a certain edge.

elements.text: It’ll give you an idea of what a returns chart would look like given a certain edge.

text: Over 1000 bets. That’s assuming all bets are independent though. Which yours won’t be if you’re betting multiple times in a race.

elements.text: Over 1000 bets. That’s assuming all bets are independent though. Which yours won’t be if you’re betting multiple times in a race.

text: I mean you could do something similar in Python or whatever over 1000 bets, given edge, 1 million simulations and see what your expected profit would be. Again, assuming bets are independent.

elements.text: I mean you could do something similar in Python or whatever over 1000 bets, given edge, 1 million simulations and see what your expected profit would be. Again, assuming bets are independent.

text: With a large enough sample size - which you don't have here - I would use the central limit theorem to treat the sum of returns as normally distributed, assume you bet with zero edge and work out the probability of observing the profit you have

text: By “very successful” do you mean very scalable? i.e. large absolute profit. Depends how we define successful.

text:
You can find very consistent strategies that win every single day. But are not that scalable. 

Or you can find strategies with massive edges, and so win consistently as well, but have very few opportunities.

elements.text: You can find very consistent strategies that win every single day. But are not that scalable.
Or you can find strategies with massive edges, and so win consistently as well, but have very few opportunities.

text: Of course, a strategy could also be considered very successful if it produces consistent low volatility returns

elements.text: Of course, a strategy could also be considered very successful if it produces consistent low volatility returns

text: Or very scalable ones (you can get a lot on) that generally have decent edges but fairly few independent bets over time which means potentially drawdowns over long periods.

elements.text: Or very scalable ones (you can get a lot on) that generally have decent edges but fairly few independent bets over time which means potentially drawdowns over long periods.

text: It takes a certain “skill” to be able to stomach those sort of returns though. Confidence that you’ve got it right!

elements.text: It takes a certain “skill” to be able to stomach those sort of returns though. Confidence that you’ve got it right!

text: Even after 10 years I only stick with strategies which are up over a month. Then scale by building more strategies. But I’m beginning to slowly accept more risky ones. That’s the plan anyway!

text:
Lee I use the Monte Carlo simulation a lot now now having been introduced to it by James and how you would apply it in context
If you were to consider the 1111 bets you had placed (lets call that a season) and then run a Monte Carlo on the implied probabilities to see if the bets were down to luck, and run it on 100,000 seasons, you will get an idea whether you have something for further investigation or not.. For eg if you were have a 95% probability that the results were not due to luck, then keep testing.
There may be more scientific methods out there, but the Monte Carlo simulation is a good yard stick I’ve found.

elements.text:
Lee I use the Monte Carlo simulation a lot now now having been introduced to it by James and how you would apply it in context
If you were to consider the 1111 bets you had placed (lets call that a season) and then run a Monte Carlo on the implied probabilities to see if the bets were down to luck, and run it on 100,000 seasons, you will get an idea whether you have something for further investigation or not.. For eg if you were have a 95% probability that the results were not due to luck, then keep testing.
There may be more scientific methods out there, but the Monte Carlo simulation is a good yard stick I’ve found.

text: One conclusion from it is that if your true edge is 10% you still need 10k _independent_ bets to have good power to detect this

Yeah, assume zero edge. Use a random number to determine if bet would have won (if rand<implied prob). Then see how often you would get the returns you got out of 100,000 simulations. 

However we’re assuming bets are independent in this case.

text:
Not yet, i'm just starting with simple strategies by venue and then try to tweak and improve them by looking for certain signals. I just tested by venue to begin with as I thought it's easy way to decide on a subset of the data which had volume.
Thats another reason why my sample size is low. I can add in more races but then i'd be choosing venues which show a profit with the strategy, which also makes me think i'm "forcing" a result rather than getting the "true" result.

elements.text:

text:
Yeah, definitely sounds like overfitting by choosing historically profitable venues without good reason. In fact if it doesn’t work for some venues then you need to question why - or it could just be your sample is too small. 

I supposed volume could be an issue if that’s somehow related to your strategy.

elements.text: Yeah, definitely sounds like overfitting by choosing historically profitable venues without good reason. In fact if it doesn’t work for some venues then you need to question why - or it could just be your sample is too small.
I supposed volume could be an issue if that’s somehow related to your strategy.

text:
I always encourage maxing out opportunities by minimising selection criteria. It reduces overfitting and it reduces time to get significance in results. A lot of systematic stuff is about having a statistical edge. But stats need big samples. So do your best to get a big sample in a short time period. 

Unless you’re happy to endure weeks or months of drawdown and backtest over years of data.

elements.text:
I always encourage maxing out opportunities by minimising selection criteria. It reduces overfitting and it reduces time to get significance in results. A lot of systematic stuff is about having a statistical edge. But stats need big samples. So do your best to get a big sample in a short time period. 

Unless you’re happy to endure weeks or months of drawdown and backtest over years of data.

text: Would it make sense to change my sample to the whole country instead of one venue and then start tweaking again?

elements.text: Would it make sense to change my sample to the whole country instead of one venue and then start tweaking again?

text:
Well without knowing what the strategy edge is supposed to be (and I guess it might not always be that clear anyway), yes, I’d include everything. 

Are you backtesting or betting live? I would personally backtest so I can try lots of variations in a short space of time, not risk money, etc... But keep a set of out-of-sample data which I can verify the strategy on afterwards.

elements.text: Well without knowing what the strategy edge is supposed to be (and I guess it might not always be that clear anyway), yes, I’d include everything.

text: From what I’ve read, flumine isn’t quite ready yet? Or just about ready for testing? That’s basically what you want to use if you don’t have a backtesting system of your own. Then you just need the data to backtest with. And hope the backtest is a good representation of live betting. Which it mostly is at low stakes and when taking volume.
